awd_titl_txt: Transforming Robot-mediated Telerehabilitation: Citizen Science for Rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
1604355 - Porfiri

Robotic devices have been playing an increasingly central role in physical rehabilitation due to their capability to support an increasing range of therapeutic treatments, minimize therapist time commitment, and record the performance of patients. To further extend rehabilitation treatments beyond clinical settings and enhance rehabilitation progress, considerable effort has been devoted toward robot-mediated telerehabilitation, which allows a physical therapist to remotely monitor and supervise several patients simultaneously. However, the cost of these devices and the repetitive nature of the prescribed exercises have significantly hampered the practicality of robot-mediated telerehabilitation. This project will open new directions for transforming robot-mediated telerehabilitation, through the integration of therapeutic treatments with low-cost haptic devices and interactive online citizen science activities. In the envisioned paradigm, participants will contribute to citizen science by performing activities that are part of their therapeutic regiment, and consequently increase the time spent on otherwise-boring rehabilitation activities. This integration is expected to not only contribute to scientific research but also increase patient self-esteem. 

This research program seeks to advance upper limb robot-mediated telerehabilitation for patients recovering from stroke by empowering them through active science participation. The envisioned system comprises a low-cost haptic joystick interfaced to a PC, which affords online social interactions in a citizen science research project. Patients will contribute to an environmental monitoring citizen science project developed by the research team, by analyzing images acquired by an aquatic mobile robot in a polluted canal in Brooklyn, NY, while interacting with other patients online. By harnessing the motivation and interests of patients in science and the environment, the proposed approach aims to maximize retention and efforts towards rehabilitation. The analysis will be performed using a haptic joystick, which provides a force-feedback to the patient while recording salient rehabilitation performance indices for upper limb rehabilitation. The system will be tested on both healthy subjects and patients undergoing rehabilitation for post-stroke hemiparesis through a series of experimental studies that elucidates the combined effects of force feedback and social interactions on patient performance and satisfaction.

por.por_cntn:
Home-based rehabilitation is often impeded by patients' lack of motivation to perform their prescribed physical exercise in the absence of a therapist, which significantly compromises rehabilitation outcomes. In this project, we developed a novel approach for engaging patients with disability in their prescribed exercise. Specifically, we integrated citizen science content into traditional rehabilitation exercises, so that patients are empowered to learn about science and advance scientific discoveries while exercising. We focused on a local environmental citizen science project that aims to monitor the quality of water in a highly-polluted canal. In the project, a robotic boat is deployed into the canal and takes pictures of its surroundings. Volunteers label landmarks and potential pollutants in the images to aid with cleaning efforts in the canal. The citizen science project was adapted for use with several low-cost interfaces and extensively tested with human subjects. Through the developed interfaces, we investigated the potential of further enhancing engagement by incorporating social interactions into citizen science-based telerehabilitation. In a series of studies, we experimentally tested the influence of social presence and cooperation on users' behavior, engagement, and satisfaction. Using behavioral, physiological, and cognitive measures, we demonstrated that each of those strategies modulates user engagement, thereby opening the door for targeted interventions in telerehabilitation. Finally, we advanced remote assessment of motor performance through the introduction of data-driven classification algorithms into our platforms. In particular, we explored different mathematical methods to pinpoint the elements that are most important for motion analysis. These efforts could enable feedback systems, benefitting both patients and practitioners. Our algorithms reached exceptionally high accuracy, thereby demonstrating the possibility of automating the motor assessment online and augmenting the time- and cost-effectiveness of telerehabilitation paradigms.

Several graduate and undergraduate students had the opportunity to work in an interdisciplinary environment and contribute to this project. They received training in software design, experimental methods, statistical analysis, and human behavior, among many other disciplines. All findings were disseminated through publications in international journals and presentations at technical conferences. The research was further promoted to diverse audiences through formal and informal learning activities, including lab tours, city-wide festivals in New York City, medical research expositions, and social media. Through these outreach events, members of the general public gained first-hand knowledge on the challenges of telerehabilitation and potential multidisciplinary approaches to mitigate them.
